description: From Middle English selde (“seat, store”), from Old English seld (noun), neuter, metathetic form of setl (noun) (English settle).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A shop. (In Medieval Latin records selda or silda (cf. Latin sella (“seat, chair”)); also in Anglo-Norman form seude). Also, a stand for spectators.

description: From Middle English selde (adjective) and selde (adverb), a back-formation from Old English seldor (“more seldom”), seldost (“most seldom”).

adjectives.description: seld (comparative more seld, superlative most seld)

examples: Synonyms: infrequent, scarce, uncommon; see also Thesaurus:rare
Synonyms: bizarre, odd, weird; see also Thesaurus:strange

adverbs.description: seld (comparative more seld, superlative most seld)

examples: knowing how far such an amitie is from the common use, and how seld seene and rarely found, I looke not to finde a competent judge.
